entry.title: UHK Keyboard review
entry.content:
Short after I came to Mexico to work, in December 2015, I found a project in Crowd Supply for a new keyboard that draw my attention, the Ultimate Hacking Keyboard (a.k.a UHK), and I decided to buy one. The characteristics that impressed me the most were that it was a mechanical keyboard (I'm a fan of mechanical keyboards) and, more important, it could split in two halves.

After a long wait (its delivery was delayed for more than two years) I can say I'm very happy with my acquisition. It's not the perfect keyboard, but it's quite close. The thing I miss the most from the keyboard are some extra keys, like the escape key or the arrow keys, but, since it's easily configurable via an agent provided by the company that make them (it's available for linux, MacOS and Windows, which is something to appreciate), I'll be doing some changes in order to be more and more comfortable with it.

As I suspected, the fact that is a mechanical keyboard make it very gentle with my fingers, and the fact that I can split it and orient it with several sideboards make me feel more natural in my posture when I write with the UHK. It also comes with a wood palm rest that is comfortable for my wrist, and the size is compact but not too small, so I can move it around from my apartment to my office in my bag and, at the same time, is not too small that I type several keys at the same time.

I know it's not a cheap keyboard, but the quality worth it, and the agent, the keyboard firmware and its schematics are free (as in Free Software), so you are not only buying a great keyboard, but supporting the Free Software and Hardware movement, apart from a honest business. I also appreciate a lot the good communication the UHK makers have, since they have shared all the process of building the keyboard and the different difficulties they have found, it's not common to find a project that open in all their path from the original idea to the final product.

The only thing I'm waiting now for is the extensions I ordered with the keyboard itself, one with a trackball to attach the mouse in the keyboard and another one with three extra keys that I plan to use to define some macros to make more automatic some recurrent tasks.

Happy Hacking!
